post.title: A friendly reminder

body:
Yes, more voting! ☑️

Here are some more great tips mentioned on the [Categorized List of Apolitical Guilds](https://ruqqus.com/post/14ee/a-categorized-list-of-apolitical-guilds) post:

### Upvote Things 👍
If you see something cool, ***upvote it***. I've posted apolitical things that get more positive comments than upvotes. On edditr with millions of users, it doesn't matter. Here, it does. Don't look at a photo and think "How nice!" without upvoting.

### Stop "free-riding" 🛑 ✍️
When things get big, they tend to follow the Pareto rule (20% of people do 80% of whatever the thing in question). In the case of small things (like, startups) everyone has to be way more active. For every session you browse Ruqqus, make sure to make at least one post.

### Forget Niches (for now) 🌟
+Music is barely at critical mass. Why focus on building +JustinBiebler or whatever until there are more users?

### Recycle ♻️
Not every post is going to be original. If you use other aggregators, there's nothing wrong with a few reposts. If you remember something cool you found 10 years okay, feel free to share it. Not everyone will have seen it.

### Use +Guilds 🛡️
If you've made a guild, made a few posts, and figured out what you want to do with it, then post it to +Guilds. If you don't make Guilds, join +Guilds to see new guilds.

---

Another great tip in my opinion would be to sort the mainpage and your various guilds by *NEW* `?sort=new`

Here are some more great tips mentioned on the Categorized List of Apolitical Guilds post:

Upvote Things 👍

If you see something cool, upvote it. I've posted apolitical things that get more positive comments than upvotes. On edditr with millions of users, it doesn't matter. Here, it does. Don't look at a photo and think "How nice!" without upvoting.

Stop "free-riding" 🛑 ✍️

When things get big, they tend to follow the Pareto rule (20% of people do 80% of whatever the thing in question). In the case of small things (like, startups) everyone has to be way more active. For every session you browse Ruqqus, make sure to make at least one post.

Forget Niches (for now) 🌟

+Music is barely at critical mass. Why focus on building +JustinBiebler or whatever until there are more users?

Recycle ♻️

Not every post is going to be original. If you use other aggregators, there's nothing wrong with a few reposts. If you remember something cool you found 10 years okay, feel free to share it. Not everyone will have seen it.

Use +Guilds 🛡️

If you've made a guild, made a few posts, and figured out what you want to do with it, then post it to +Guilds. If you don't make Guilds, join +Guilds to see new guilds.

Another great tip in my opinion would be to sort the mainpage and your various guilds by NEW ?sort=new

body:
I actually hate the upvote system. I think it inevitably leads to a mess of a system. At least if the votes are public.

Low effort comments are made just for points, and users get the pleasure of seeing people "like" their comments. Likewise, it creates a mob mentality. If someone makes a valid point, but it's disliked by the first people to get to the comment, it gets buried, and the people who see the negative numbers think, "Oh, this person said something that I knew was out of the ordinary, and now all of these other users are confirming for me that it's a stupid comment, so I'll downvote it as well." And any post filled with stupidity, making poor arguments or factually inaccurate statements, gets upvoted so that it has a higher impact on the community.

I don't know where the fix is. But I avoid upvoting when I think someone is being stupid. I don't downvote, either. I don't think votes should mean right or wrong. What are they for, then? Good arguments? Useful comments? There aren't many of those. Combining upvotes for "this made me snicker" comments with "this is a legitimately thoughtful argument" comments just confuses things.

Even if someone's engaging in good faith, why would I upvote someone who's being a *moron* in good faith?

It's all a mess. I hate it. Votes power the system, but they also destroy it.
body_html:
I actually hate the upvote system. I think it inevitably leads to a mess of a system. At least if the votes are public.

Low effort comments are made just for points, and users get the pleasure of seeing people "like" their comments. Likewise, it creates a mob mentality. If someone makes a valid point, but it's disliked by the first people to get to the comment, it gets buried, and the people who see the negative numbers think, "Oh, this person said something that I knew was out of the ordinary, and now all of these other users are confirming for me that it's a stupid comment, so I'll downvote it as well." And any post filled with stupidity, making poor arguments or factually inaccurate statements, gets upvoted so that it has a higher impact on the community.

I don't know where the fix is. But I avoid upvoting when I think someone is being stupid. I don't downvote, either. I don't think votes should mean right or wrong. What are they for, then? Good arguments? Useful comments? There aren't many of those. Combining upvotes for "this made me snicker" comments with "this is a legitimately thoughtful argument" comments just confuses things.

Even if someone's engaging in good faith, why would I upvote someone who's being a moron in good faith?

It's all a mess. I hate it. Votes power the system, but they also destroy it.

body:
i remember when i joined reddit. there was really just one sub. i wanted to participate in and it had restrictions on karma that you needed in order to post/comment. so I tried making comments in other subs and on the lame frontpage material. 

i ended up getting downvoted into oblivion on my first few comments. the hivemind was so sensitive, even back then before it was SJW central. what's worse is that I was trying to be funny and get upvotes, not trolling and being provocative.

body:
If you want to submit an image, you can upload it directly to ruqqus (i.ruqqus.com is the url those images will be linked as), but **only after you reach 1000 rep points**. This is to prevent, among other things, bad faith users signing up for ruqqus and then uploading perhaps illegal content just to cause trouble for the site.

Until you reach 1000 rep, you can still link images, but you have to go to some other website, upload them there, then find the appropriate url to copy over and submit to ruqqus as you would submit any other link. It's just a messier process. Plus, sites like imgur are now requiring registration (including a phone number) to see NSFW albums, etc. Uploading to ruqqus is just many times more convenient.

parent.body:
Yes, more voting! ☑️

Here are some more great tips mentioned on the [Categorized List of Apolitical Guilds](https://ruqqus.com/post/14ee/a-categorized-list-of-apolitical-guilds) post:

### Upvote Things 👍
If you see something cool, ***upvote it***. I've posted apolitical things that get more positive comments than upvotes. On edditr with millions of users, it doesn't matter. Here, it does. Don't look at a photo and think "How nice!" without upvoting.

### Stop "free-riding" 🛑 ✍️
When things get big, they tend to follow the Pareto rule (20% of people do 80% of whatever the thing in question). In the case of small things (like, startups) everyone has to be way more active. For every session you browse Ruqqus, make sure to make at least one post.

### Forget Niches (for now) 🌟
+Music is barely at critical mass. Why focus on building +JustinBiebler or whatever until there are more users?

### Recycle ♻️
Not every post is going to be original. If you use other aggregators, there's nothing wrong with a few reposts. If you remember something cool you found 10 years okay, feel free to share it. Not everyone will have seen it.

### Use +Guilds 🛡️
If you've made a guild, made a few posts, and figured out what you want to do with it, then post it to +Guilds. If you don't make Guilds, join +Guilds to see new guilds.

---

Another great tip in my opinion would be to sort the mainpage and your various guilds by *NEW* `?sort=new`

If I didn't like voting on posts, I’d just go to a traditional forum.

parent.body:
If you want to submit an image, you can upload it directly to ruqqus (i.ruqqus.com is the url those images will be linked as), but **only after you reach 1000 rep points**. This is to prevent, among other things, bad faith users signing up for ruqqus and then uploading perhaps illegal content just to cause trouble for the site.

Until you reach 1000 rep, you can still link images, but you have to go to some other website, upload them there, then find the appropriate url to copy over and submit to ruqqus as you would submit any other link. It's just a messier process. Plus, sites like imgur are now requiring registration (including a phone number) to see NSFW albums, etc. Uploading to ruqqus is just many times more convenient.

body:
It takes time to catch on to what they like. Most redditors aren't intelligent enough to understand the better material, so they denounce it as "trolling" and downvote and ban those users, while the normie stuff is upvoted to the top. When I first joined almost everything I posted got lots of downvotes and rude replies. Just 100 upvotes was very high for me back then. I even had at least one stalker downvote everything I posted immediately (probably using a bot since it was watching me 24/7, and the funniest part is they were stupid enough to make their votes public so I discovered them a year later). A lot of times, the lamer the better.

And as far as commenting goes, you need to sort by rising/new (the latter requires a bit of judgement) so you get the first few comments before the post blows up. The way the sorting algorithm works is that new comments are immediately buried at the bottom and never seen, and the ones that already have upvotes remain mostly in place.
body_html:
It takes time to catch on to what they like. Most redditors aren't intelligent enough to understand the better material, so they denounce it as "trolling" and downvote and ban those users, while the normie stuff is upvoted to the top. When I first joined almost everything I posted got lots of downvotes and rude replies. Just 100 upvotes was very high for me back then. I even had at least one stalker downvote everything I posted immediately (probably using a bot since it was watching me 24/7, and the funniest part is they were stupid enough to make their votes public so I discovered them a year later). A lot of times, the lamer the better.

And as far as commenting goes, you need to sort by rising/new (the latter requires a bit of judgement) so you get the first few comments before the post blows up. The way the sorting algorithm works is that new comments are immediately buried at the bottom and never seen, and the ones that already have upvotes remain mostly in place.

parent.body:
If you want to submit an image, you can upload it directly to ruqqus (i.ruqqus.com is the url those images will be linked as), but **only after you reach 1000 rep points**. This is to prevent, among other things, bad faith users signing up for ruqqus and then uploading perhaps illegal content just to cause trouble for the site.

Until you reach 1000 rep, you can still link images, but you have to go to some other website, upload them there, then find the appropriate url to copy over and submit to ruqqus as you would submit any other link. It's just a messier process. Plus, sites like imgur are now requiring registration (including a phone number) to see NSFW albums, etc. Uploading to ruqqus is just many times more convenient.

body:
The logical strategy is to never upvote though. So in pure game theory terms, if you want to max rep, you have to post and never upvote. Which leads to a lack of upvotes overall, which hurts growth, etc. 

It's essentially the Savings Paradox, but with internet points.

The only cure would be to have a different system in place.

body:
I hate these systems too. They were designed to 'gamify' online conversation by shady corporations and only really serve to create addictions and make people easier to manipulate.

It just makes people skim the top posts under the assumption that there's nothing worth reading below a certain point, and anything highly voted probably won't get challenged because people generally don't like to go against the grain - especially when there's self-esteem points at steak. It's mob rule - and we've seen what that's done to Twitter.

It's my only real stumbling block with Ruqqus at the moment. It'd probably be a bastard to change the coding though.

parent.body:
I actually hate the upvote system. I think it inevitably leads to a mess of a system. At least if the votes are public.

Low effort comments are made just for points, and users get the pleasure of seeing people "like" their comments. Likewise, it creates a mob mentality. If someone makes a valid point, but it's disliked by the first people to get to the comment, it gets buried, and the people who see the negative numbers think, "Oh, this person said something that I knew was out of the ordinary, and now all of these other users are confirming for me that it's a stupid comment, so I'll downvote it as well." And any post filled with stupidity, making poor arguments or factually inaccurate statements, gets upvoted so that it has a higher impact on the community.

I don't know where the fix is. But I avoid upvoting when I think someone is being stupid. I don't downvote, either. I don't think votes should mean right or wrong. What are they for, then? Good arguments? Useful comments? There aren't many of those. Combining upvotes for "this made me snicker" comments with "this is a legitimately thoughtful argument" comments just confuses things.

Even if someone's engaging in good faith, why would I upvote someone who's being a *moron* in good faith?

It's all a mess. I hate it. Votes power the system, but they also destroy it.

I actually hate the upvote system. I think it inevitably leads to a mess of a system. At least if the votes are public.

Low effort comments are made just for points, and users get the pleasure of seeing people "like" their comments. Likewise, it creates a mob mentality. If someone makes a valid point, but it's disliked by the first people to get to the comment, it gets buried, and the people who see the negative numbers think, "Oh, this person said something that I knew was out of the ordinary, and now all of these other users are confirming for me that it's a stupid comment, so I'll downvote it as well." And any post filled with stupidity, making poor arguments or factually inaccurate statements, gets upvoted so that it has a higher impact on the community.

I don't know where the fix is. But I avoid upvoting when I think someone is being stupid. I don't downvote, either. I don't think votes should mean right or wrong. What are they for, then? Good arguments? Useful comments? There aren't many of those. Combining upvotes for "this made me snicker" comments with "this is a legitimately thoughtful argument" comments just confuses things.

Even if someone's engaging in good faith, why would I upvote someone who's being a moron in good faith?

It's all a mess. I hate it. Votes power the system, but they also destroy it.

parent.body:
Yeah, a lot of people here have left other big social media. I've been thinking about just going over to r/dankmemes and reposting all good (In my opinion) memes to +dankmemes just to energize the place, I don't have the time or creativity to make original memes myself a lot of the time, I don't want to go on Twitter to screenshot posts and post that to +TumblrInAction because I don't want to go on Twitter as a principle, same with Tumblr, etc. etc. I can't create most content myself... but I could repost stuff through my own quality filter to get this place up and running.

It might be worth it.
